stream_context.summary: In a bonus stream, Kaze worked on the desert level. The main activities included debugging and fixing a broken vanilla Pokey enemy, adding NPCs and coins to make the town area feel more alive, and grappling with a significant RAM limitation that forced him to cut a planned 'Yoshi Ranch' area from the level.

development_findings.summary: Due to running out of RAM in the desert level, Kaze made the decision to cut an entire area, the 'Yoshi Ranch', reframing the technical necessity as a design improvement by calling the area 'unnecessary fluff'.
development_findings.quote: We're definitely gonna have to cut to Yoshi Ranch, which is sad, but it is what it is. Honestly, I'm fine with cutting out the Yoshi Ranch. I think that was unnecessary fluff anyway.

development_findings.summary: Kaze spent a significant portion of the stream debugging the vanilla Pokey enemy, whose behavior was broken by custom engine optimizations. The fix involved forcing the Pokey's body segments to update their floor collision every frame, even when stationary.
development_findings.quote: Remember when I said that I wouldn't be surprised? If the pokey just worked This is what we got this is pokey peak performance.

development_findings.summary: The team is using narrative tricks, like having bandits steal items from stores, to avoid modeling extra assets and conserve memory.
development_findings.quote: This is a trick we do so we don't actually have to 3D model the stuff here because we are getting pretty close to running out of RAM.

development_findings.summary: Kaze implemented a more precise algorithm for generating random rotations compared to the original Mario 64, making every randomly rotated object (like a tumbleweed) unique and theoretically making it easier to detect speedrun cheaters.
development_findings.quote: In this game, every rotation is unique, because we actually use a signed approximation algorithm instead of a rounded lot. So actually, you could catch a cheater pretty easily in this game.

development_findings.summary: Kaze added new visual effects to the train obstacles, including VFX, SFX, and camera shake, to make them more impactful.
Kaze is intentionally adding more NPCs and coin placements to make the desert town level feel more alive and guide the player.
The desert level is unusually memory-intensive (40,000 triangles), causing crashes and forcing design cuts. The root cause of its high cost compared to other levels is not fully clear.
development_findings.quote: Why is it just this one level that's so expensive? What makes this level so much more expensive than the other ones?

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses cynicism about game jam competitions, believing they reward pandering to the audience and that organizers often bend their own rules, such as extending deadlines.
context_findings.quote: I've always said the comps, you don't win it by making good hacks. You win it by playing to the audience and stuff like that.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has a strong philosophical preference for direct, precise language over metaphorical or idiomatic expressions, viewing the latter as 'noise'.
context_findings.quote: I think idioms are really dumb. I don't like them because like why are people making idioms like just say the words you want to say bro. I value language that is concise and precise.

context_findings.summary: Kaze states that he dislikes most games, particularly 2D platformers and boss fights, which informs his own design philosophy.
context_findings.quote: You guys need to realize I hate games. When you say you would love this game, I always thinking where this guy doesn't know me at all.

context_findings.summary: Kaze acknowledges the 'Ship of Theseus' problem when discussing how much of the game's code is his versus Nintendo's, indicating a blurry line between original work and modification.
context_findings.quote: It's the ship of the size meme. I'll show you guys to jump NPC here. He's very funny.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is experiencing significant issues with PayPal, which closed his account after a prolonged and unresolved identity verification process, forcing him to use an old German account and complicating his stream donations.
Kaze shares a cynical view on game design educators, suggesting they are likely individuals who were not successful enough to be professional game designers.
context_findings.quote: Who would go to a school to teach game design? It would have to be someone who wasn't as successful as a game designer, right? Because if they had been successful as a game designer and they liked game design, they would be a game designer.

biobak.summary: Kaze humorously laments a texture issue, presumably from Biobak, where an object was not receiving lighting correctly, requiring Kaze to debug and fix it.
biobak.quote: Why, Biobak? Why? Why would you do this to us?

badub.summary: Kaze praises Badub's music for creatively using the Mario 64 sound font to create something that feels new yet retains a similar vibe to the original, which aligns perfectly with Kaze's vision for the soundtrack.
badub.quote: It's freaking amazing like how different from the default Mario 64 sound. Most of it is still the default Mario 64 sound font... but they're used in really creative ways. So it sounds like a completely new soundtrack with like a similar vibe to me. That's what I want anyway.

zeina.summary: Kaze plans to ask Zeina to create animations for the Pokey enemy.
zeina.quote: Gonna ask Zeno to make animations for this guy here.

zeina.summary: Kaze needs Zeina to create a 3D model for a 'tumbleweed store' for the level's town area.
zeina.quote: I gotta ask Zeina to make a tumbleweed store here.

key_stories.title: Fixing the Broken Pokey
key_stories.summary: Kaze discovered the standard Pokey enemy was non-functional in his engine. After a lengthy debugging process, he found that his own performance optimizations conflicted with the Pokey's original, inefficient code which required 37 raycasts per frame. He fixed the issue, showcasing a common challenge in ROM hacking: new systems breaking old, unoptimized ones.
key_stories.challenge: The vanilla Pokey enemy from Mario 64 was completely broken in the custom engine. Its body segments were invisible, misplaced high in the air, or had incorrect scaling and collision.
key_stories.process: Kaze systematically investigated the bug by comparing his code to the original, printing debug information, and stubbing out functions. He identified that his engine's optimization, which prevented static objects from raycasting to save performance, was breaking the Pokey. He disabled this optimization for the Pokey parts and also fixed issues with its model orientation, scale, and shadow.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully debugged and fixed the Pokey. He discovered the root cause was his engine's optimization conflicting with the Pokey's need for constant floor checks. After fixing the logic, scaling, and orientation, the Pokey now functions correctly and can be placed throughout the level.
key_stories.key_quote: Why was a Pokey doing 37 Raycasts every tick? To find the same floor over and over. And my engine made it so that if an object doesn't move it doesn't Raycast the floor every tick. But they needed the floor to be Raycasted every tick.

key_stories.title: Cutting the Yoshi Ranch Due to RAM Limitations
key_stories.summary: The ambitious desert level exceeded the N64's RAM capacity, causing the game to crash. Faced with this hard technical limit, Kaze made the tough design decision to cut an entire planned area, the 'Yoshi Ranch', to ensure the rest of the level could function.
key_stories.challenge: While working on the large desert level, the game began crashing upon loading, indicating that the level was exceeding the N64's RAM limits.
key_stories.process: Kaze first confirmed the crash was memory-related. He investigated using a memory overlay, which gave confusing results by showing significant free space. Despite the confusing data, he decided the most practical solution was to reduce the level's scope by removing a visually and geometrically complex area.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze decided to cut an entire planned section of the level, the 'Yoshi Ranch', to reduce memory usage and resolve the crashing. He rationalized the decision by deeming the area 'unnecessary fluff', turning a technical limitation into a design choice.
key_stories.key_quote: We're definitely gonna have to cut to Yoshi Ranch, which is sad, but it is what it is.

open_questions.context: Kaze discovered the desert level was crashing due to RAM limitations. However, when he used a memory overlay tool, it reported a large amount of free memory, confusing him. He cut content anyway to be safe.
questions: Can you walk me through the mystery of the RAM issue? Why do you think the memory overlay showed free space while the game was still crashing?
How does the decompilation project handle memory allocation differently from traditional ROM hacking, and how does that create challenges like this?
How do you decide what to cut when you hit a technical wall like this? What made the Yoshi Ranch the right thing to remove?

open_questions.context: When asked about the legality of his engine modifications, Kaze referenced the 'Ship of Theseus' paradox, acknowledging that the line between his code and Nintendo's is blurry.
questions: You mentioned the 'Ship of Theseus' when talking about your code versus Nintendo's. Creatively and technically, where do you personally draw that line?
How much of the original engine do you feel you have to respect, and where do you feel free to build something completely new?
Does this legal gray area ever cause you anxiety or influence your design decisions?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned needing to ask his wife, Zeina, to create animations for the Pokey and a model for a 'tumbleweed store'.
questions: What is your collaborative workflow with Zeina like? How do you go from an idea in the stream to a finished asset in the game?
How do you two handle creative disagreements, blending a professional and personal relationship?
Can you give an example of a time Zeina's artistic input significantly changed or improved one of your initial ideas?

open_questions.topic: Musical Direction and Collaboration with Badub
open_questions.context: Kaze praised Badub's music, noting that it uses about 70% of the original Mario 64 sound font but in creative ways to achieve a new sound with a 'similar vibe'.
questions: What was the initial conversation with Badub like when defining the musical direction for the game?
Can you describe the feedback process? How do you communicate abstract ideas about 'vibe' and 'feel' for a new track?
Was there a particular track from Badub that made you realize he completely understood the vision for the project?

open_questions.context: Kaze has very strong, stated opinions, such as hating 2D platformers and boss fights, and valuing conciseness in language over artistry.
questions: You've said you hate most games, especially 2D platformers and boss fights. How do these strong preferences shape the design of 'Return to Yoshi's Island'?
Are there any 'rules' you set for yourself in your designs based on these likes and dislikes?
Does this ever put you at odds with player expectations for a Mario-style game?
